To determine the Best Workplaces for Women, Great Place to Work® surveyed over 400,000 U.S. employees from Great Place to Work-Certified companies and ranked companies based on four factors: (1) Key Great Place to Work Metrics. They analyzed how positively women rated their organizations on over 50 different metrics defining great workplaces, including ethical leadership, respectful and fair workplace interactions, great benefits and development, and strong caring and personal support. (2) Comparison to Colleagues. They compared women's results on all survey questions to that of their male colleagues. Specifically, they looked at an index of factors where the data showed women often lag their peers, such access to leaders and information, and recognition for their work. (3) A Consistent Experience within a Diverse Group. They analyzed demographic patterns to ensure that companies were creating great workplaces for all women, regardless of who they are or what they do for the organization. (4) A Consistent Experience within a Diverse Group. They analyzed demographic patterns to ensure that companies were creating great workplaces for all women, regardless of who they are or what they do for the organization. Companies needed to employ at least 50 women to be considered.

As part of FLA, some of the world's leading brands have committed to ensuring fair labor practices and safe and humane working conditions throughout their supply chains. Companies that have committed to FLA's Code of Conduct and established systems to identify and remedy ethical violations are making significant strides towards that goal. These companies are working with FLA to develop and improve social compliance systems that flag issues and lead to sustainable solutions when workers are at risk. Companies join the FLA on a voluntary basis, but they must meet strict labor standards for as long as they are affiliated. FLA holds Participating Companies accountable for monitoring 100% of their own supply chains to ensure that they meet FLA labor standards.

answerIconAdaDescription.S: Icon for Fair Labor Association Members

answerSubText.S: Fortune list of 100 Best Companies to Work For 2018.

Publicly traded companies whose business involves using the earth’s heat energy for productive use, such as generating electricity and space and process heat. These companies' 10-K's were checked to assess whether they use geothermal methods to produce energy or not.

Waste-to-energy stocks are publicly traded companies whose business involves using municipal or other waste as a feedstock to create fuel or electricity. These companies' 10-K's checked to confirm why they are considered renewables.

answerSubText.S: Companies affected by the Cluster Munitions and Anti-Personnel Mines Act. The Cluster Munitions and Anti-Personnel Mines Act 2008 prohibits the investment of public money, either directly or indirectly, in any company involved in the manufacture of prohibited munitions or components. Public money is defined in the Act as “moneys provided by the Oireachtas out of the Central Fund”; thus, the application does not extend to private investors.
